   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:21.3/38.5/2.0, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:/44/0.23, ALT / AST:42/53, Alk Phos / T Bili:139/,
   Differential-Neuts:94.7 %, Lymph:3.6 %, Mono:1.2 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.2 mmol/L, Ca++:8.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:5.4 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. Dopamine
   dependent post cath.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA 325mg PO daily, Plavix 75mg PO daily
   -hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel pending
   - HbA1c pending
   -CEs in am
   # PUMP:  EF unknown. No elevated filling pressures on right heart
   cath.
   -TTE pending
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.
   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am pending
   # Hypotension - requiring dopamine post cath, likely in setting of RV
   infarct.  Also may have been try prior to procedure as was found down
   after an undefined period of time prior to OSH admission with ARF.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.
   -stat HCT unchanged (30 on admission, 28 on repeat after several liters
   of fluids)
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Ddx includes early renal failure vs
   possible aggressive IVF with NS.  No evidence GI losses.
   -Switch to LR for hydration.
   -monitor renal function
   -serial ABGs
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. On bair hugger. In setting of
   hypotension and leukocytosis (although both can likely be explained by
   MI), will be wary of developing sepsis. TSH WNL.  Also possible in
   setting of malnutrition (pt appears cachectic, albumin is low), or may
   be inaccurate temp in setting of cardiogenic shock.
   -CBCd in am
   -Blood and urine cx, UA bland at OSH.
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate tomorrow, initiate TF.
   Agressive IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now, contact, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 322**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 3872**]

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly man who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient is currently in the ICU and is intubated with mechanical ventilation. Here are the potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is consistently low, indicating ongoing hypotension. This requires close monitoring and adjustment of fluid administration and vasopressor support.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure, and there is evidence of mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. There is a need to optimize ventilator settings, ensure adequate oxygenation, and consider weaning off mechanical ventilation as tolerated.

3. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's serum creatinine levels have increased from 1.1 at OSH to 1.4 here, indicating possible worsening renal function. Close monitoring of renal function and appropriate management, such as fluid restriction and diuretics, should be considered.

4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which can be caused by aggressive IV fluid administration or early renal failure. It is important to monitor electrolyte levels, acid-base balance, and renal function.

5. Hypothermia: The patient is persistently hypothermic, and the temperature on admission was 94.7 degrees Fahrenheit. Measures should be taken to rewarm the patient, including the use of warming devices

   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   Hypotensive overnight responsive to dopamine and increased volume.
   Dobutamine strated for inotropic support.
   CVP today 8-10 mmHg.
   Physical Examination
   As recorded.
   Medical Decision Making
   day 2 post large infero-posterior MI.  Hemodynamic status complex with
   probable evidence of RV infarction but low to normal right sided
   filling pressures despite large volume resuscitation.  Low SVR based on
   numbers formo cardiac cath possibly consistent [**Doctor Last Name 3897**] sepsis or SIRS
   related to large MI.  For now will continue moderate volume to keep CVP
   >8 and <15 and attempt to wean dopamine if SBP >100.
   Lung mass of uncertain cause - will follow.
   Plan to reduce sedation and extubate in next 24 hours.
   Total time spent on patient care: 30 minutes of critical care time.
   Additional comments:
   Critical care due to hemodynamic instability, ventialtor.

1. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which is likely due to cardiogenic shock caused by the inferior STEMI and RV dysfunction. This requires careful monitoring and management with appropriate fluid resuscitation and inotropic support.

2. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated in the setting of a code at OSH and is currently on mechanical ventilation. There is a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis as indicated by the ABG results. Close monitoring and titration of ventilator settings are necessary to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

3. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): The patient's serum creatinine levels have increased from 1.1 to 1.4, suggesting possible ARF. Further evaluation and management are required, including close monitoring of renal function, appropriate fluid balance, and avoidance of nephrotoxic agents.

4. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient initially presented with a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which resolved with fluid resuscitation. Continued monitoring is essential to ensure that the acid-base balance does not deteriorate further.

5. Hypothermia: The patient was hypothermic upon admission, with a temperature of 94.7 degrees Celsius. It is important to monitor the patient's temperature closely and take appropriate measures to maintain normothermia.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old man with limited medical history who presented to the hospital with an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) of the right coronary artery (RCA). He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His initial acidosis improved overnight, allowing for a reduction in FiO2. However, he experienced increasing hypotension and required escalation of vasopressor support with dopamine and dobutamine. Fluid resuscitation was also administered. The patient's urine output has been low, and he is persistently hypothermic. An arterial line has been placed. 

Assessment and Plan:
1. Coronary artery disease: The patient had an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He is dependent on vasopressors post-catheterization. Hold beta-blockers until hemodynamic stability is achieved, and then consider weaning off pressors. Administer aspirin, Plavix, and high-dose statin. Perform lipid panel and HbA1C for risk stratification.
2. Cardiac function: The patient's response to IV fluids suggests right ventricular (RV) dysfunction, possibly related to the ischemic territory. However, the central venous pressure (CVP) is low. Perform a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) today to assess cardiac function. Bolus IV fluid for low urine output

   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS. Dopamine
   dependent post cath.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix, hold BB until HD stable
   -High dose statin
   -Lipid panel and HbA1C for risk stratification
   .
   # PUMP:  Responding to IV fluids suggesting RV dysfunction possibly
   related to ischemic territory, however, CVP is low.  EF unknown. No
   elevated filling pressures on right heart cath.
   -TTE today
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.
   -monitor on tele
   -ECG in am
   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic, on dopamine and dobutamine.
   Pulsus 10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis,
   since hypothermic to 95, cultures and imaging thus far negative.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   have some contribution from positive pressure ventilation as well.
   - Monitor culture results
   -IVF prn
   -CVP goal >15
   -Pressors (dopamine + dobutamine for inotropy prn) goal MAP >60
   -a-line
   -if persistently hypotensive may need PA catheter for improved
   monitoring, likely L SC approach.
   -repeat ABG, decrease PEEP if tolerated
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.
   -mucomyst
   -bicarb
   -hydration
   -continue to monitor
   .
   # Respiratory failure - apparently intubated in setting of code at
   OSH.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
   -increase RR
   -Titrate down Fi02 as tolerated
   -f/u CXR
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass - No known malignancy history.
   -Review OSH films with rads
   -discuss PMH with family/prior PCP (if any)
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO overnight, if no plan to extubate, initiate TF. Agressive
   IVF.  Lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ in place, comes out in am (as was placed at OSH), needs new
   CVL if still requiring pressors. A-line.
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV
   CODE: Presumed full

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient underwent PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) of the RCA (right coronary artery).
- The patient is intubated and overbreathing on the ventilator.
- Initially, the patient had acidosis, which improved overnight, allowing for weaning of FiO2.
- The patient experienced increasing hypotension, for which dopamine was started at a catheter level and increased up to 15ug/kg/min. The patient was also given fluids and dobutamine, resulting in a combination of dopamine at 8ug/kg/min and dobutamine at 5ug/kg/min.
- The patient received 4L fluids overnight.
- The patient's urine output was initially low around 30mL/hour but improved to 70mL/hour with boluses.
- The patient remained persistently hypothermic.
- An arterial line (A-line) was placed.
- The patient's vital signs included a temperature of 37.2C (98.9F), heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 87/47 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%.

Medical Complications that can arise:
1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and low CVP indicate possible cardiogenic shock due to inferior STEMI and total occlusion of the RCA.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with a pulmonary nodule, myocardial infarction (AMI), hypotension, and hypothermia. The patient is receiving various medications including dobutamine, midazolam, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F), heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 65/78 mmHg to 132/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 5,305 mL and output of 1,462 mL, resulting in a balance of 3,843 mL. The patient's blood products total out is 1,462 mL, urine output is 1,232 mL, and NG output is 230 mL.

The patient's laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 9.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, sodium of 125 mg/dL, potassium of 4.3 mEq/L, and glucose of 125 mg/dL. Other lab values are within normal ranges.

The patient has an arterial line and multi-lumen line in place for monitoring and administration of medications. 

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), stress ulcers due to the use of pantoprazole, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to prolonged immobilization, and catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI) from the arterial and multi-lumen lines. Close monitoring and appropriate interventions should be implemented to prevent these complications.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an elderly man who is currently in the ICU. He has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition is stable, with controlled vital signs and adequate oxygenation. However, there are several medical complications that can arise.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: Due to the patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation, there is an increased risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): This is a type of pneumonia that occurs in patients who have been mechanically ventilated for more than 48 hours.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and use of central venous catheters increase the risk of developing blood clots in the legs.
4. Pulmonary embolism: If a DVT dislodges and travels to the lungs, it can cause a potentially life-threatening pulmonary embolism.
5. Myocardial infarction: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, which puts him at risk for a heart attack while in the ICU.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate potential kidney dysfunction, which can be exacerbated by medications or inadequate fluid management.
7. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and sensory deprivation from being intubated can lead to delirium.
8. Stress ulcers: Intensive care unit admission is associated with an increased risk of stress ulcer development

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI and subsequently underwent RCA revascularization. The patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with several medical complications.

1. Coronary artery disease: The patient had a total occlusion of the RCA and previously underwent BMS placement. He is now dependent on dopamine due to post-cath complications. The plan includes holding beta-blockers until hemodynamic stability is achieved, weaning off pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IV fluid administration for preload augmentation, and starting ASA, Plavix, and a high-dose statin.

2. Pump dysfunction: The patient's heart is responding to IV fluids, suggesting RV dysfunction possibly related to the ischemic territory. However, the CVP is low, and the ejection fraction (EF) is unknown. A TTE has been ordered to further evaluate the pump function. The plan includes continuing aggressive IV fluid administration for preload augmentation and closely monitoring the patient's response.

3. Rhythm disturbances: The patient's rhythm has been NSR at present but has been increasingly tachycardic on the evening of admission. The plan includes monitoring the patient's heart rate, conducting regular ECGs, and considering a PA catheter if the patient remains hypotensive despite pressor therapy.

4. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and on dopamine and dobutamine

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented from the outside hospital (OSH) with an inferior STEMI, subsequent RCA revascularization, and currently depends on dopamine/dobutamine for hemodynamic support post catheterization. The patient has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE.

The assessment and plan include the following:

1. Coronaries: The patient should not need ionotropic support, so weaning dobutamine and titrating up dopamine as needed. Hold BB until HD stable, high-dose statin, and lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24. HbA1C is 5.7.

2. Pump: Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory, however, CVP is low, and RV function appeared normal on TTE yesterday. No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%. Bolus IV fluid for low urine output <30cc.

3. Rhythm: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of admission. Now improved. Monitor on tele, holding BB given hypotension.

4. Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, on dopamine and dobutamine. Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic function on TTE. Appears to be more distributive now. Pulsus 10 on exam

The patient's arterial blood gas shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure readings are low, indicating hypotension. This could be due to cardiogenic or septic shock.    80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p

   .
   # Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, currently on
   neosynephrine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Differential includes acute adrenal
   insufficiency.Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus 10 on exam.
   No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since was
   hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative.  Does have
   cavitary lesion in R lung apex and lesion in liver, ? abscess or other
   infectious process.  Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may
   also be contributing.
   - Monitor culture results
   - cont IVF boluses, now s/p 3 units of pRBCs today
   - wean pressors today as tolerated
   - check free cortisol this AM, if low consider [**Last Name (un) **] stim to rule out
   adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory failure - intubated in setting of code at OSH.  No known
   h/o lung disease.  ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic
   acidosis.  Patient currently on FiO2 of 50% with assist control.
   Patient is not hypoventilated based on his ABG.
   - wean sedation this morning
   - attempt for SBP and possible extubation trial
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix
   -continue high dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid for low urine output < 30cc
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.1 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for
   sepsis, WBC curve and temperature curve.
   .
   # Lung/liver mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.

   - ruling out for TB, [**2-11**] sputums sent

   - negative pressure room

   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as

   -SW c/s

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented to the emergency department with an inferior STEMI. He underwent RCA revascularization and was admitted to the CCU. The patient attempted to wean sedation yesterday but was unable to move his arms or legs. He was placed on CPAP and then back on assist control ventilation in the afternoon. Blood cultures are negative so far, and blood pressure has been labile all day. Dobutamine was discontinued and titrated up dopamine initially, but the patient's blood pressure would fluctuate between 200 systolic and 70s off. Norepinephrine is currently being used at a dose of 0.03 mcg/kg/min. The patient received 3 units of packed red blood cells after not responding to 2 units, and his central venous pressure (CVP) appears to have responded well to fluid repletion.

Infusions include norepinephrine, fentanyl, and pantoprazole. The patient also received heparin sodium prophylaxis. Other medications include aspirin, Plavix, and a high-dose statin. The patient's HbA1C level is 5.7.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Hypotension - The patient's hypotension is currently being treated with norepinephrine. The differential includes cardiogenic, septic, and hypovolemic causes. Given the

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented from outside with an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He underwent RCA revascularization and is now in the ICU. The patient is dependent on dopamine and dobutamine for hemodynamic support, has mild inferior hypokinesis on transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), and shows an ejection fraction (EF) of 45-50%. 

Potential Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Hypotension: The patient is on dopamine and dobutamine, suggesting hypotension. However, preserved systolic function on TTE makes cardiogenic hypotension less likely.
2. Sepsis: The patient was hypothermic to 95 degrees Fahrenheit on admission, cultures are negative so far, and there are cavitary lesions in the right lung apex and liver, raising concerns for an infectious process such as abscesses. Positive pressure ventilation and sedation may also contribute to hypotension.
3. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure during a code at OSH. No known history of lung disease, and the ABG shows mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): Unclear baseline creatinine, with values of 1.1 at OSH and 1.4 here. Creatinine improved to 1.2 today after hydration

Summary:
The patient is a 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented to the emergency department with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient has been in the ICU for ongoing stabilization and management of multiple medical complications.

Key findings from the progress note include:
1. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing labile blood pressure, requiring titration of dopamine and norepinephrine. There is a concern for cardiogenic, septic, or hypovolemic causes, but the preserved systolic function on TTE suggests less likely cardiogenic hypotension. Pulsus paradoxus is present, and there is concern for sepsis, given the negative cultures so far. Sedation and positive pressure ventilation may also be contributing factors.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated in the setting of a code and has no known history of lung disease. ABG shows mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis. The patient is currently on FiO2 of 50% with assist control and is not hypoventilated based on the ABG.
3. Coronaries: The patient had an IMI with total occlusion of RCA, which was treated with BMS placement. The patient is dependent on dopamine/dobutamine post catheterization and has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE.
4. Pump: Initial concern for RV dysfunction due to ischemic territory, but CVP is low, and RV function appeared normal on T

The patient's 24-hour events include attempts to wean sedation, opening eyes to voice but unable to move arms or legs, placement on CPAP and then back on AC in the afternoon, uptitrating dopamine as needed with excellent blood pressure control, negative urine and blood cultures, initiation of norepinephrine at 0.3 mcg/kg/min due to labile blood pressure, administration of 3 units of packed red blood cells, and fluid resuscitation.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate of 53 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 104/38 mmHg to 235/77 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 94%, and sinus bradycardia. 

The patient's lab results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, hematocrit, platelet count, sodium, potassium, chloride, bicarbonate, BUN, creatinine, and liver function tests. However, the patient has an elevated troponin-T level and elevated lactate level.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of inferior STEMI, who presented to the hospital with respiratory failure. He was intubated and treated for aspiration pneumonia, which was confirmed by sputum culture. The patient also had an episode of bradycardia resulting in a code blue, and his blood pressure has been labile. He has a history of COPD and clubbing, and his lungs show signs consistent with COPD and a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. He is currently on BiPAP and showing improvement in his respiratory status. The patient's mental status is altered, and he has flaccid limbs with depressed reflexes. He has metabolic acidosis, possibly due to aggressive IV fluids. The patient's coronary arteries show mild inferior hypokinesis, and there is a concern for lung mass and possible malignancy or TB. He is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics for the aspiration pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive at times, requiring the use of vasopressors such as dopamine and dobutamine. This could indicate poor cardiac function or volume depletion.
2. Bradycardia: The patient experienced an episode of bradycardia leading to a code blue. The cause of this bradycardia is unclear, but it may be related to the aspiration pneumonia or a primary neurological event.
3. Respiratory failure:

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of limited known medical problems. He presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient has been experiencing multiple medical complications since admission.

1. Hypotension: The patient initially required dopamine and dobutamine for hypotension but is now back on dopamine due to recurrent hypotension. The differential diagnosis includes cardiac causes, neurologic causes, acute stroke, metastatic disease, or anoxic brain injury.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated during a code at OSH due to respiratory failure. There is no known history of lung disease, but the chest X-ray shows findings consistent with COPD and a rib fracture from chest compressions. The patient also has clubbing of the fingers. The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear, but it may be due to hypoventilation of COPD, aspiration pneumonia, or a diffusion defect.

3. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient has evidence of aspiration pneumonia, as indicated by the presence of oropharyngeal flora in sputum cultures and a cavitary lesion on chest X-ray. He was started empirically on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.

4. Coronaries: The patient had an inferior myocardial infarction with total occlusion of the RCA, which was treated with a bare-metal stent (BMS).

The patient is currently in the critical care unit (CCU) with multiple medical complications.

1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with shock/hypotension, which is now less likely to be cardiogenic given preserved systolic function on transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE). The differential diagnosis includes distributive shock (e.g., septic shock), hypovolemic shock, or acute adrenal insufficiency. However, the cortisol level was within normal limits, making acute adrenal insufficiency less likely. There is concern for sepsis, as the patient was hypothermic upon admission, cultures are pending, and the chest X-ray is concerning for aspiration pneumonia (PNA). The patient has also developed bradycardia and hypotension overnight, which responded to atropine and pressors. Chest compressions were given due to recurrent loss of consciousness (LOCs), which could be due to these vagal events of unclear etiology. The patient is currently on dopamine for pressure support as the blood pressure was very labile on norepinephrine after the code blue event on 02/15.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   .
   # Shock/Hypotension - Cardiogenic vs. septic vs. hypovolemic, currently
   on dopamine.  Now less likely cardiogenic given preserved systolic
   function on TTE.  Differential includes acute adrenal insufficiency but
   cortisol level was WNL. .Appears to be more distributive now.  Pulsus
   10 on exam. No evidence PTX on exam or CXR.  Concern for sepsis, since
   was hypothermic to 95 on admission, cultures thus far negative, but CXR
   concerning for aspiration PNA.  Does have cavitary lesion in R lung
   apex.
   - Monitor culture results
   - cont IVF boluses
   - wean pressors today as tolerated
   - Continue BiPAP for now with minimal PEEP to prevent worsening
   hypotension from poor venous return
   - CODE BLUE on [**2166-2-15**]. Developed bradycardia and hypotension overnight.
   Seemed vagal ? [**2-10**] mucous plugging. Trending CEs for evidence of
   recurrent coronary event. Responded to atropine and pressors. Chest
   compressions were given. His recurrent LOCs could be due to these vagal
   events of unclear etiology
   - Currently on dopamine  for pressure support as BP was very labile on
   norepi after his CODE BLUE on [**2166-2-15**]
   - Concern for aspiration PNA and component of sepsis. Started
   empirically on vanco+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**].
   .
   # Respiratory failure - intubated in setting of code at OSH.  No known
   h/o lung disease but CXR consistent with COPD and has clubbing one
   exam.  The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear. [**Name2 (NI) **] is
   hypoventilating [**2-10**] his COPD and rib Fx from compressions. Also clearly
   tiring from respiratory effort. There does not seems to be a diffusion
   defect as he has oxygenated well throughout this hospitalization. Also
   a component of aspiration PNA is complicating and even etiologic to his
   presentation.
   - Extubated successfully on [**2166-2-15**].
   - ABG here shows a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis which had
   initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated.
   - CXR consistent with aspiration PNA with ongoing RUL cavitary lesion
   which pre-dates his respiratory distress
   - Sputum Cx during intubation growing oropharyngeal flora consistent
   with aspiration PNA
   - Given above concerns for aspiration, started empirically on
   vanc+pip/tazo on the evening of [**2166-2-15**]
   - Patient currently on FiO2 of 50% with PEEP 5 and pressure support of
   10. He seems to be tolerating this well
   .
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   Dopamine/dobutamine dependent post cath.  Has mild inferior hypokinesis
   on TTE.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Wean pressors as tolerated, favoring aggressive IVF for preload
   augmentation.
   -ASA, plavix
   -continue high dose statin on PO access available
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24. This metabolic
   picture is consistent with poor nutrition and generally poor metabolic
   state
   - HbA1C 5.7
   .
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal om TTE yesterday.
   No elevated filling pressures on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   .
   # RHYTHM: NSR at present. Increasingly tachycardic on evening of
   admission.  Now improved
   -monitor on tele
   - Holding BB given hypotension
   .
   # Lung mass
 Has RUL cavitary lesion on CT as well as lesion in
   liver.  Concerning for TB vs. malignancy, no known TB risk factors.
   Pulmonary not planning to bronch during this admission
   - ruling out for TB, [**2-11**] sputums sent
   - ppd placed on [**2-13**] (L forearm) appears NL
   - negative pressure room
   - OSH films loaded into PACS
   - discuss further PMH with family today when they arrive
   - AFBs x 3 pending
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Pt with ongoing poor orientation and not fully
   communicative. Improved post-extubation. Nevertheless, has ongoing
   flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes. Could be consistent with ICU
   neuropathy v anoxic brain injury or CVA.
   .
   # ARF - Unclear baseline, cr 1.1 at OSH on admission, 1.4 here.  Cr
   imporved to 1.1 today after hydration.  Likely ARF in setting of
   hypovolemia given improving with IVF.
   - continue to monitor
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis, non AG. Resolved with fluids. Recurred with
   multiple boluses. Complicated by some degree of respiratory acidosis.
   .
   # Hypothermia - Temp 94.7 on admission. Monitor culture data for

   .
   #Psychosocial - pt found down, both he and his household decribed as
   unkept.  Unclear if safe alone at home
   -SW c/s
   -PT when able.
   .
   FEN: NPO currently, nutrition consult for TFs.  IVF boluses prn as

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited medical history who presented from outside with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He has been in the ICU for several days, experiencing multiple complications. These include hypotension requiring vasopressors, respiratory failure requiring intubation and extubation, COPD with a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe, aspiration pneumonia, altered mental status, mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis, and potential coronary artery disease. The patient's condition remains unstable, and several potential medical complications may arise.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of STEMI and RCA revascularization indicates underlying coronary artery disease. His current dependence on vasopressors suggests possible cardiac dysfunction. There is a risk of further cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial ischemia.

2. Respiratory Complications: The patient has been intubated and extubated multiple times, indicating significant respiratory distress. He has COPD with a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe, which may be due to infection or malignancy. The risk of respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation, aspiration pneumonia, or worsening lung lesions remains high.

3. Neurological Complications: The patient exhibits altered mental status and poor orientation, which could be attributed to ICU neuropathy, anoxic brain injury, or a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited medical history who presented from outside with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He was initially hypotensive and required dopamine/dobutamine, and had an episode of hypotension/bradycardia during which a code was called. The patient continues to have small pressor requirements and is currently on dopamine at 5mcg/kg/min. He has been extubated and tolerating facemask, but with some difficulty weaning off oxygen. The patient has clubbing on examination and a history of COPD, and his respiratory failure etiology is unclear. He has a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe consistent with aspiration pneumonia, for which he is being empirically covered with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient's coronary arteries are diseased due to a total occlusion of the RCA, for which he underwent stenting. He has mild inferior hypokinesis on TTE and persistent pressor requirement. The patient's mental status is altered, with poor orientation and communication, but has improved post-extubation. He also exhibits flaccid limbs and depressed reflexes, which may be due to ICU myopathy. His lipid panel shows low LDL and HDL levels. The patient has a lung mass with a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe and a lesion in the liver, raising concerns for tuberculosis or malignancy

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multiple medical conditions. The patient has a history of full code status and is currently on dopamine infusion at 4 mcg/kg/min. The patient's vital signs show a heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 105/48 to 181/140 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's neurological exam reveals movement in the right upper extremity, some movement in the left upper extremity, and limited lower extremity movement. The patient tolerated taking oral Plavix and was able to wear a facemask for 50%. The patient's blood glucose levels have been within a relatively stable range.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Myocardial Infarction (MI): The patient has a history of acute myocardial infarction. Given the ongoing chest pain and elevated cardiac markers, there is a risk of further complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pulmonary status is concerning, with a pulmonary nodule present on imaging. This could indicate pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory distress and sepsis.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Immobility in the ICU increases the risk of developing blood clots, particularly in the lower extremities. If left untreated, DVT can lead to pulmonary embolism.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly man with limited past medical history who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient initially required dopamine and dobutamine due to hypotension but experienced an episode of hypotension and bradycardia during which a code was called. The patient continues to have small pressor requirements and is uncertain whether cardiogenic shock is the cause or if there are other potential etiologies.

The patient has been intubated and extubated successfully, tolerating a facemask and weaning down on oxygen. There is a concern for aspiration pneumonia (ASP PNA) due to the presence of a cavitary lesion on the right upper lobe (RUL) of the lung, which pre-dates his respiratory distress. Empirically, the patient was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.

The patient's coronary arteries show total occlusion of the right coronary artery (RCA) with previous myocardial infarction (MI) and bare-metal stent (BMS) placement. The patient remains dependent on dopamine and dobutamine post-catheterization and still requires persistent pressor support. Inferior hypokinesis is noted on the transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE).

The patient's altered mental status/neuro deficits include poor orientation and inability to fully communicate. The patient's limbs are flaccid, and

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of limited medical history who presented from outside with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He was initially hypotensive, requiring dopamine/dobutamine, then switched to levo. The patient was extubated but later became bradycardic and hypotensive, so he is now back on dopamine and IV fluids for hypotension. The differential diagnosis for his new episode includes primarily cardiac issues, but there are no ECG changes or increase in cardiac enzymes, suggesting a possible vagal episode or aspiration. Other possible causes include primary neurological processes, acute stroke, metastatic disease, or anoxic brain injury. The patient has been started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and is planned for an 8-day course, with ID approval today.

The patient also has respiratory failure, intubated during a code at outside hospital, with no known history of lung disease but consistent with COPD and clubbing on examination. The etiology of his respiratory failure is unclear, with a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis that initially resolved but has returned now that he is extubated. The patient has a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe of the lung, which predates his respiratory distress, and sputum cultures during intubation are growing oropharyngeal flora consistent with aspiration pneumonia. Empirical coverage with vancomycin plus piperacillin-tazobactam was started

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a full code status. The patient has been on dopamine infusion at 7/hr due to hemodynamic instability, but an attempt to wean it off resulted in a significant drop in heart rate. The patient's neurological exam showed some movement in the right upper extremity (RUE) and left upper extremity (LUE), but minimal movement in the lower extremities (LE). The patient tolerated oral intake and was able to take PO Plavix. The patient's vital signs were relatively stable with a blood pressure in the 130s/80s, heart rate in the 70s, respiratory rate in the 30s, and oxygen saturation at 100%. The patient's CVP was low at 3 mmHg, and fluid balance showed an intake of 2,650 mL with an output of 1,390 mL. The patient's blood gases showed a pH of 7.26, PaCO2 of 26, and HCO3 of 21. The patient's labs showed elevated white blood cell count (WBC) at 13.8 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin (Hct) at 32.0%, and elevated troponin-T level at 0.35 ng/mL. Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

1. The patient experienced a vagal-like reaction with a drop in pulse and blood pressure. The reaction was managed with an increase in dopamine and did not require chest compressions.
2. The patient's sputum grew Acinetobacter baumannii, which is sensitive to piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient was placed on contact precautions.
3. The patient was evaluated by an electrophysiologist (EP) regarding repeated vagal events. It was decided to hold off on a pacemaker for now.
4. A neurologist consulted about the patient's neurologic condition, specifically the development of flaccidity. The neurologist believed that the differential diagnosis includes watershed infarcts in the spine or brain and recommended an MRI of the brain and spine. However, the patient is not considered stable for an MRI at this time, so the recommendation will be readdressed actively.

   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p

   # Hypotension
 Pt s/p inferior STEMI, initially hypotensive requiring
   dopamine/Dobutamine current on dopamine only. Had episode of
   hypotension/bradycardia [**2-15**] during which code was called, repeat
   bradycardia with code blue on [**2166-2-17**] appeared to be in setting of
   either vagal episode or aspiration PNA.  Episode of [**2166-2-17**] was in the
   setting of dropping NG tube down. Initially thought to be fluid
   responsive.  Unclear if persistently hypotensive due to cardiogenic
   shock (unlikely given TTE) vs other potential etiologies.  Differential
   diagnosis includes adrenal insufficiency, cardiogenic, hypovolemic, or
   acute bleed. Patient with crit drop this morning in the setting of
   arterial line and repeat intubation, no obvious source of bleeding.  ?
   if some central process is playing a role.  In terms of evaluation for
   adrenal insufficiency initial random cortisol 21 which is normal,
   however in ICU patient on pressors and intubated would expect value to
   be higher so may represent relative adrenal insufficiency. TSH 0.87
   which is WNL.
   - Dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP<60.
   - F/u cx, covering broadly with vanc/zosyn for asp pna, planned 8 day
   course.  Started evening of [**2-15**]
 covers both blood culture as well as

   for 5 days from [**2166-2-18**] to [**2166-2-22**] and then taper dose.
   - [**Month (only) 11**] be complicated by ongoing moderate upper GI bleeding (see below)
   # Respiratory failure
 initially intubated in setting of code at OSH.
   No known h/o lung disease but CXR consistent with COPD and has clubbing
   on exam.  Likely aspiration during code on [**2-15**], on antibiotics.
   Patient was increasingly tachypneic after code yesterday and acidotic,
   requiring reintubation last evening.  The etiology of his respiratory
   failure is likely multifactorial. He is hypoventilating secondary his
   COPD and rib Fx from compressions.  Also a component of aspiration PNA.
   There does not seem to be a diffusion defect as he has oxygenated well
   throughout this hospitalization.
   - Wean vent as tolerated

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited known medical history who presented from the operating room (OSH) with an inferior STEMI, subsequently undergoing RCA revascularization. The patient experienced hypotension and bradycardia on two separate occasions, leading to code blues. The initial hypotension/bradycardia episode occurred during the code on 2-15 and the second episode happened during the arterial line placement on 2-17. Both episodes were associated with asphyxiation events. The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, requiring dopamine support and IV fluid boluses for MAP < 60. The patient's respiratory status has been deteriorating, necessitating reintubation due to tachypnea and acidosis. The chest x-ray revealed findings consistent with COPD and clubbing. The sputum culture grew Acinetobacter baumannii sensitive to piperacillin/tazobactam, prompting the initiation of contact precautions.

The patient also experienced an upper gastrointestinal bleed, with frank blood observed in gastric aspirates. Protonix was administered IV and started as a drip, along with the transfusion of additional packed red blood cells. The patient's coronary status is complicated by ongoing moderate upper GI bleeding, which is being closely monitored by the GI team.

Neurological deficits, including poor orientation, altered mental status, and flaccid limbs with depressed reflexes, have been present since extubation. A neurology

   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   # Hypotension
 Multifactorial.  Initially thought to be cardiogenic
   [**2-10**] inferior MI, responded to dopamine/norepinephrine.  Also possible
   hypovolemia, since volume responsive at times.  There was concern for
   bleeding given falling hematocrit and transiently improved pressor
   requirement after transfusions.  Lastly, having several prolonged vagal
   episodes with vagal stimuli with pauses resulting in hypotension, so
   may have some autonomic dysfunction.  Also, Cosyntropin stimulation
   test was
   abnormal suggesting component of adrenal insufficiency.
   - Appreciate Neurology and EP input regarding profound vagal episodes
   - Dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP<60,wean as
   tolerated
   - Vancomycin for staph in blood culture, Zosyn for acinetobacter in
   sputum, day 1=[**2166-2-15**]
   - Goal CVP 8-10
   - Continue empiric corticosteroids
   - Treat GI bleeding as needed
   # Respiratory failure
 Multifactorial due to impaired gas exchange
   from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics given recent
   chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease.
   Fluid overload less likely given absence of significant oedema on
   x-rays.
   - Treat pneumonia, plan for 8-day course of Zosyn for acinetobacter.
   - Wean vent as tolerated
   - f/u AFB neg. x3, now off precautions.
   # UPPER GI BLEEDING: Gastroccult positive OG tube contents, perhaps
   related to insertion trauma. Currently stable
   - Monitor serial hematocrits, PPI gtt, and transfuse for Hct < 30 or
   drop  more than 5 points
   - Continue to have IV access x2
   - Keep type & screen up to date
   - Continue ASA and Plavix as needed to maintain stents
   - Consider restarting tube feeds today
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Bolus prn for BP and UOP.
   -Wean pressors as tolerated
   -ASA, plavix
   -high dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24.
   - HbA1C 5.7
   # Altered Mental Status/neuro deficits: After extubation Pt had ongoing
   poor orientation, not fully communicative, flaccid limbs, depressed
   reflexes.  Distribution with b/l LE and LUE>RUE without clear
   suggestions of anatomic lesion.  Toxic-metabolic workup thus far
   negative.  Also with recurrent autonomic instability with multiple
   vagal episodes leading to code blue.
   - Appreciate neurology input, Plan for MRI brain and spine today
   - B12, folate, RPR, TSH, wnl here
   -thiamine repletion, aggressive nutritional support
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal on TTE and filling
   pressures not elevated on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   -no BB, ACEI while on pressors
   # RHYTHM: Repeated vagal episodes resulting in loss of pulse.
   Appreciate EP and Neurology input regarding same.
   - Holding BB given hypotension, bradycardia.
   -telemetry
   # Lung mass
 TB rule-out.  Per pulmonary, warrants outpatient
   evaluation after stabilization of acute issues.
   FEN: OG tube, start tube feeding after MRI today. Replete lytes prn.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of limited known medical problems who presented to the emergency department with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient experienced hypotension that responded to dopamine and norepinephrine, suggesting cardiogenic shock initially. However, it was later determined to be multifactorial due to hypovolemia, bleeding, and autonomic dysfunction.

The patient also had profound vagal episodes with pauses resulting in hypotension, which may indicate some autonomic dysfunction. Additionally, the patient had an abnormal cosyntropin stimulation test, suggesting adrenal insufficiency.

In terms of respiratory failure, the patient had impaired gas exchange from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics due to recent chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease. Fluid overload is less likely given the absence of significant edema on x-rays.

The patient was treated with antibiotics for staph in blood culture and acinetobacter in sputum. The goal CVP was set at 8-10, and empiric corticosteroids were continued. Treatment for GI bleeding was provided as needed.

For coronary artery disease, the patient had a total occlusion of RCA and underwent BMS placement. Beta-blockers were held temporarily until off pressors. ASA and Plavix were continued, along with high-dose statin therapy.

Regarding altered mental status/neuro deficits, the patient had poor

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of limited known medical problems who presented from outside with an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), and subsequently underwent right coronary artery (RCA) revascularization. The patient experienced several complications including hypotension, respiratory failure, upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, altered mental status/neuro deficits, and recurrent vagal episodes.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's initial hypotension was thought to be cardiogenic due to an inferior MI. There is a possibility of cardiogenic shock developing if the heart function further deteriorates.

2. Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia caused by Acinetobacter baumannii, which is a multi-drug resistant organism. Proper infection control measures need to be continued to prevent the spread of infection.

3. GI bleeding: Although the patient is currently stable, there is a risk of re-bleeding or worsening of the current condition. Close monitoring and appropriate management of the GI bleeding is necessary.

4. Neurological deficits: The patient has altered mental status and neurologic deficits, which may be due to a stroke or other neurological causes. Further evaluation, including an MRI, is recommended to determine the underlying cause and guide treatment.

5. Autonomic dysfunction: The patient has experienced recurrent vagal episodes leading to hypotension

   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   # Hypotension
 Likely Multifactorial.  Initially thought to be
   cardiogenic [**2-10**] inferior MI, responded to dopamine/norepinephrine.
   Also possible hypovolemia, since volume responsive at times.  There was
   concern for bleeding given falling hematocrit and transiently improved
   pressor requirement after transfusions.  Lastly, having several
   prolonged vagal episodes with vagal stimuli with pauses resulting in
   hypotension, so may have some autonomic dysfunction.  Also, Cosyntropin
   stimulation test was
   abnormal suggesting component of adrenal insufficiency.
   - Appreciate Neurology and EP input regarding profound vagal episodes
   - Dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP<60,wean as
   tolerated
   - d/c Vancomycin yesterday as staph epidermis in blood culture only
   from one bottle and likely contaminant
   - changed to Unasyn [**2166-2-19**] (from Zosyn)  for pansensitive
   acinetobacter in sputum, day 1=[**2166-2-15**], would complete 8 day course
   - Goal CVP 8-10, fluid bolus to maintain
   - Continue empiric corticosteroids x 5 days
   - Treat GI bleeding as needed, crit has been stable
   # Respiratory failure
 Multifactorial due to impaired gas exchange
   from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics given recent
   chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease.
   Fluid overload less likely given absence of significant edema on
   x-rays.  Patient becoming more alkalotic on vent, primarily
   respiratory, will decrease PS to 12 today.
   - Treat pneumonia, plan for 8-day course of Unasyn for acinetobacter.
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily trials of breathing
   - f/u AFB neg. x3, now off precautions.
   # UPPER GI BLEEDING: Gastroccult positive OG tube contents, perhaps
   related to insertion trauma however may be independent bleed. Currently
   stable.  Evaluated by GI who deferred EGD given Hct stable and no
   further bleeding noted.
   - Monitor serial hematocrits, changed PPi to [**Hospital1 **], transfuse for Hct <
   25 or drop  more than 5 points
   - Continue to have IV access x2
   - Keep type & screen up to date
   - Continue ASA and Plavix as needed to maintain stents
   - restarted tube feeds will increase free water flushes
   - pm Hct today
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Bolus prn for BP and UOP.
   -Wean pressors as tolerated
   -ASA, plavix
   -high dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24.
   - HbA1C 5.7
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Plt since admission have dropped from 366 -> [**Age over 90 **]
   yesterday which is greater than 50% drop.  Time course is consistent
   with possible HIT.  Heparin products d/c
d yesterday and HIT Ab sent.
   DIC labs negative.  PPI can cause thrombocytopenia, however favor
   continuing given recent GIB.  Held off starting argatroban given risk
   of bleeding and no evidence of thrombotic events at this time.
   - Holding heparin products
   - f/u HIT Ab
   - Start argatroban if develops thrombosis or HIT positive
   # Altered Mental Status/neuro deficits: After extubation Pt had ongoing
   poor orientation, not fully communicative, flaccid limbs, depressed
   reflexes.  Distribution with b/l LE and LUE>RUE without clear
   suggestions of anatomic lesion.  Toxic-metabolic workup thus far
   negative.  Also with recurrent autonomic instability with multiple
   vagal episodes leading to code blue.
   - Appreciate neurology input, Plan for MRI brain and spine today
   - B12, folate, RPR, TSH, wnl here
   -thiamine repletion, aggressive nutritional support
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal on TTE and filling
   pressures not elevated on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   -no BB, ACEI while on pressors
   # RHYTHM: Repeated vagal episodes resulting in loss of pulse.
   Appreciate EP and Neurology input regarding same.
   - Holding BB given hypotension, bradycardia.
   -telemetry
   # Lung mass
 TB rule-out.  Per pulmonary, warrants outpatient
   evaluation after stabilization of acute issues.
   FEN: OG tube, restart tube feeding today. Inc. free water flushes for
   hypernatremia.  Replete lytes prn.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented from the outside hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He has been experiencing hypotension, which is likely multifactorial in origin. There are concerns about cardiogenic shock due to the inferior MI, hypovolemia, autonomic dysfunction, and adrenal insufficiency. The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial as well, caused by impaired gas exchange from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics due to recent chest compressions, and possible underlying obstructive lung disease. The patient also has upper GI bleeding, possibly related to insertion trauma or an independent bleed, and is currently stable. There are concerns about thrombocytopenia, possibly due to HIT, and altered mental status/neuro deficits with poor orientation, not fully communicative, flaccid limbs, depressed reflexes. The patient's pump function is normal despite initial concerns for RV dysfunction. The rhythm is primarily bradycardia, possibly due to vagal episodes. Lung mass is being evaluated for tuberculosis. The patient has been receiving various treatments and medications for his conditions, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and corticosteroids.

The patient experienced hypotension initially thought to be cardiogenic but later found to be multifactorial, possibly due to hypovolemia, bleeding, autonomic dysfunction, and adrenal insufficiency. The patient is currently on dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP <60, weaning as tolerated. 

The patient also has respiratory failure due to impaired gas exchange from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics from recent chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease. Treatment includes weaning vent as tolerated, treating pneumonia, and monitoring for fluid overload.

Additionally, the patient has an upper GI bleeding that is stable and being monitored with serial hematocrits, PPI gtt, and transfusion for Hct <30 or drop of more than 5 points. The patient's coronary arteries show total occlusion of RCA with stent placement. 

The patient has altered mental status/neuro deficits with ongoing poor orientation, not fully communicative, flaccid limbs, depressed reflexes. Toxic-metabolic workup is negative, and the patient awaits neurology input and MRI brain and spine.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited medical history who presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He has been experiencing hypotension, respiratory failure, upper GI bleeding, altered mental status, and neuro deficits. The patient's condition is multifactorial, with potential causes including cardiogenic shock, hypovolemia, autonomic dysfunction, and adrenal insufficiency. 

Medical Complications:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with several medical conditions. The patient has been stable most of the day but experienced bradycardia when trying to wean off dopamine. The patient's platelet count has been trending down since admission, raising the possibility of HIT (Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia). All heparin products have been discontinued, and a HIT antibody test has been sent. Due to the high bleeding risk, Argatroban has been held off. The patient has also been switched to a high-dose PPI (proton pump inhibitor) and fungal markers have been sent.

The patient is receiving several infusions, including fentanyl, midazolam, dopamine, and was previously receiving heparin sodium prophylaxis. The patient's medical and family history are unchanged from admission, except as noted below.

The review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the events mentioned earlier. The flow sheet data shows vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, and other parameters. The patient's temperature, blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation are within normal limits.

   Assessment and Plan
   80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization
   # Hypotension
 Likely Multifactorial.  Initially thought to be
   cardiogenic [**2-10**] inferior MI, responded to dopamine/norepinephrine.
   Also possible hypovolemia, since volume responsive at times.  There was
   concern for bleeding given falling hematocrit and transiently improved
   pressor requirement after transfusions.  Lastly, having several
   prolonged vagal episodes with vagal stimuli with pauses resulting in
   hypotension, so may have some autonomic dysfunction.  Also, Cosyntropin
   stimulation test was
   abnormal suggesting component of adrenal insufficiency.
   - Appreciate Neurology and EP input regarding profound vagal episodes
   - Dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP<60,wean as
   tolerated
   - d/c Vancomycin yesterday as staph epidermis in blood culture only
   from one bottle and likely contaminant
   - changed to Unasyn [**2166-2-19**] (from Zosyn)  for pansensitive
   acinetobacter in sputum, day 1=[**2166-2-15**], would complete 8 day course
   - Goal CVP 8-10, fluid bolus to maintain
   - Continue empiric corticosteroids
   - Treat GI bleeding as needed, crit has been stable
   # Respiratory failure
 Multifactorial due to impaired gas exchange
   from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics given recent
   chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease.
   Fluid overload less likely given absence of significant edema on
   x-rays.
   - Treat pneumonia, plan for 8-day course of Unasyn for acinetobacter.
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily trials of breathing
   - f/u AFB neg. x3, now off precautions.
   # UPPER GI BLEEDING: Gastroccult positive OG tube contents, perhaps
   related to insertion trauma however may be independent bleed. Currently
   stable
   - Monitor serial hematocrits, changed PPi to [**Hospital1 **], transfuse for Hct <
   25 or drop  more than 5 points
   - Continue to have IV access x2
   - Keep type & screen up to date
   - Continue ASA and Plavix as needed to maintain stents
   - restarted tube feeds will increase free water flushes
   # CORONARIES:  s/p IMI, with total occlusion of RCA, s/p BMS.
   -Hold BB for now until off pressors
   -Bolus prn for BP and UOP.
   -Wean pressors as tolerated
   -ASA, plavix
   -high dose statin
   -Lipid panel shows LDL below goal (39), HDL only 24.
   - HbA1C 5.7
   # Altered Mental Status/neuro deficits: After extubation Pt had ongoing
   poor orientation, not fully communicative, flaccid limbs, depressed
   reflexes.  Distribution with b/l LE and LUE>RUE without clear
   suggestions of anatomic lesion.  Toxic-metabolic workup thus far
   negative.  Also with recurrent autonomic instability with multiple
   vagal episodes leading to code blue.
   - Appreciate neurology input, Plan for MRI brain and spine today
   - B12, folate, RPR, TSH, wnl here
   -thiamine repletion, aggressive nutritional support
   # PUMP:  Initial concern for RV dysfunction given ischemic territory,
   however, CVP is low and RV function appeared normal on TTE and filling
   pressures not elevated on right heart cath. TTE shows EF 45-50%
   - Bolus IV fluid as above for BP.
   -no BB, ACEI while on pressors
   # RHYTHM: Repeated vagal episodes resulting in loss of pulse.
   Appreciate EP and Neurology input regarding same.
   - Holding BB given hypotension, bradycardia.
   -telemetry
   # Lung mass
 TB rule-out.  Per pulmonary, warrants outpatient
   evaluation after stabilization of acute issues.
   FEN: OG tube, start tube feeding after MRI today. Replete lytes prn.
   ACCESS: LIJ removed, RIJ placed [**2-13**], arterial line placed [**2-17**]
   PROPHYLAXIS:  Hep SC, bowel regimen, PPI IV

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of limited past medical history who presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. He has been in the ICU since admission and has developed several medical complications. These include hypotension, respiratory failure, upper GI bleeding, coronary artery disease, altered mental status/neuro deficits, and rhythm disturbances.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been consistently low, requiring the use of vasopressors such as dopamine and norepinephrine. There are multiple factors contributing to his hypotension, including cardiogenic shock from the inferior STEMI, hypovolemia, and autonomic dysfunction.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is dependent on mechanical ventilation due to impaired gas exchange caused by aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics from recent chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease. He has been treated for pneumonia with a planned 8-day course of Unasyn for acinetobacter.

3. Upper GI Bleeding: The patient had a positive Gastrocult test indicating bleeding in the upper gastrointestinal tract. It is unclear if the bleeding is related to trauma from the OG tube insertion or an independent source. He is currently stable, and his hematocrit levels are being monitored. Prophylactic measures include continued use of PPI, transfusion for Hct < 25 or drop of more than 5

Summary:
The patient is a 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented to the emergency department with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has multiple medical complications.

1. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive and required pressor support. The cause of hypotension is multifactorial, including cardiogenic shock due to inferior MI, hypovolemia, potential bleeding, and autonomic dysfunction. The patient also has an abnormal cosyntropin stimulation test suggesting adrenal insufficiency.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient has impaired gas exchange due to aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics from recent chest compressions, and possibly underlying obstructive lung disease. There is no evidence of fluid overload on x-rays. The patient's condition is becoming more alkalotic on the ventilator, primarily respiratory, so the pressure support level will be decreased to 12 today.

3. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB): The patient has evidence of UGIB, which may be related to OG tube insertion trauma or an independent bleed. The patient's hematocrit is stable, and no further bleeding has been noted. Monitoring of serial hematocrits is recommended, and the patient should be transfused for a hematocrit less than 25 or a drop of more than 5 points. The patient will continue to have IV access x2 and keep a type & screen up to date

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with limited known past medical history who presented to the hospital with an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and subsequently underwent right coronary artery (RCA) revascularization. The patient experienced hypotension, which was initially thought to be cardiogenic due to the inferior MI but later responded to dopamine and norepinephrine. It was also determined that some of the hypotension could be attributed to blood loss caused by thrombocytopenia and prolonged vagal episodes resulting in pauses and hypotension.

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including impaired gas exchange from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics due to recent chest compressions, possibly underlying obstructive lung disease, and now bloody secretions. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation.

Additionally, the patient has an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, which was identified through a positive Gastrocult test of the oral gastric (OG) tube contents. This bleeding may be related to insertion trauma or an independent bleed. The patient's hematocrit (Hct) is stable, and no further bleeding has been observed.

The patient also has thrombocytopenia with a significant drop in platelet count since admission. This is consistent with possible heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Heparin products have been discontinued, and HIT antibodies are pending. The

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with limited past medical history who presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization. The patient has been experiencing several medical complications since admission.

1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial and initially thought to be cardiogenic due to an inferior MI. However, it responded to dopamine/norepinephrine, suggesting possible hypovolemia as well. The patient also had transiently improved pressor requirement after transfusions and experienced prolonged vagal episodes with pauses resulting in hypotension. An abnormal cosyntropin stimulation test suggests a component of adrenal insufficiency.

Plan:
- Appreciate Neurology and EP input regarding profound vagal episodes.
- Dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP<60, wean as tolerated.
- Discontinue Vancomycin due to suspected contaminant.
- Change to Unasyn for pansensitive acinetobacter in sputum.
- Goal CVP 8-10, fluid bolus to maintain.
- Continue empiric corticosteroids x 5 days.
- Treat GI bleeding as needed, crit has been stable.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

1. The patient is an 80-year-old male with limited medical history who presented from the outside hospital with an inferior STEMI and underwent RCA revascularization.
2. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which is likely multifactorial. It initially responded to dopamine and norepinephrine but later improved with volume responsiveness and autonomic dysfunction.
3. The patient also has signs of profound vagal episodes with pauses resulting in hypotension.
4. A Cosyntropin stimulation test was abnormal, suggesting adrenal insufficiency.
5. The patient is being treated with dopamine for pressure support and IVF boluses for MAP < 60, to be weaned as tolerated.
6. Vancomycin was discontinued due to a likely contaminant in the blood culture, and the patient is now on Unasyn for pansensitive acinetobacter in sputum.
7. The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial due to impaired gas exchange from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics from recent chest compressions, and possible underlying obstructive lung disease.
8. The patient is being treated for pneumonia with an 8-day course of Unasyn and will have daily trials of breathing while on the ventilator.
9. The patient has an upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which is currently stable. It may be related to insertion trauma or an independent bleed.
10. The patient has a history of inferior myocardial infarction with total occlusion of the RCA and has undergone BMS placement.
11. The patient's platelet count has dropped significantly since admission, which is consistent with possible heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Heparin products have been discontinued, and HIT antibodies are negative.
12. The patient has altered mental status/neuro deficits, including poor orientation, flaccid limbs, and depressed reflexes. An MRI brain and c-spine have been performed, but there are no obvious lesions. Lyme serology is positive, most likely representing a chronic previous infection.
13. The patient's pump function appears normal on TTE, with an ejection fraction of 45-50%.
14. The patient has experienced repeated vagal episodes resulting in loss of pulse.
15. A lung mass has been identified, and tuberculosis is being ruled out.
16. The patient is receiving prophylaxis for pneumoboots, bowel regimen, and PPI IV.
17. The patient's current disposition is to remain in the CCU for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Continued hypotension and autonomic dysfunction.
2. Development of further respiratory failure or complications related to the lung mass.
3. Recurrence of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Progression of neurologic deficits or development of new neurological issues.
5. Thrombocytopenia or further complications related to possible HIT.
6. Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or worsening pump function.
7. Infection or sepsis due to immunocompromised state or indwelling lines.
8. Further evaluation and management of the identified lung mass.
9. Potential complications related to long-term ventilation and sedation.
10. Monitoring and management of electrolyte imbalances and glycemic control.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information, and additional details may be necessary for a comprehensive assessment.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of limited medical problems who presented to the hospital with an inferior STEMI. He underwent RCA revascularization and was initially thought to have cardiogenic hypotension due to the inferior MI. However, it was later determined that the hypotension was likely multifactorial, involving blood loss due to thrombocytopenia, autonomic dysfunction, and adrenal insufficiency. The patient is currently receiving dopamine for pressure support and IV fluid boluses to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) below 60, with plans to wean as tolerated.

The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure, which is multifactorial in nature. It is believed to be caused by impaired gas exchange from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics following recent chest compressions, possible underlying obstructive lung disease, and now bloody secretions. The treatment plan includes obtaining a CTA chest for pulmonary embolism (PE), treating pneumonia with an 8-day course of Unasyn for Acinetobacter, and weaning the ventilator as tolerated with daily trials of breathing.

The patient has an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed, which is currently stable. A gastrocult test was positive for OG tube contents, and the bleed may be related to insertion trauma or independent.    80M with limited known PMH presented from OSH with inferior STEMI, s/p
   RCA revascularization. Continues to be intubated with multiple
   complications including thrombocytopenia, difficult to control BPs,
   bradycardia, and paresis.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Likely Multifactorial.  Initially thought to be
   cardiogenic [**2-10**] inferior MI, responded to dopamine/norepinephrine.
   Some due to blood loss due to thrombocytopenia.  Lastly, having several
   prolonged vagal episodes with vagal stimuli with pauses resulting in
   hypotension, so may have some autonomic dysfunction.  Also, Cosyntropin
   stimulation test was
   abnormal suggesting component of adrenal insufficiency.
   - Appreciate Neurology and EP input regarding profound vagal episodes
   - Now off dopamine for pressure support.
   - Goal CVP 8-10. Stable now. Holding off on additional IVF boluses as
   very volume overloaded and UOP acceptable at about 30mL/hr
   - d/ced vancomycin as Staph epidermis in blood culture only from one
   bottle and likely contaminant
   - Changed to Unasyn [**2166-2-19**] from Zosyn  for pansensitive acinetobacter
   in sputum, day 1=[**2166-2-15**]
   - Changed again to cipro on [**2166-2-21**] as Pt developed thrombocytopenia
   which could be [**2-10**] Unasyn.
   - Continue empiric corticosteroids x 5 days. Begin steroid taper
   overnight 2/14-15/09
   - Transfuse for hematocrit < 25
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 Multifactorial due to impaired gas exchange
   from aspiration/lung mass, impaired chest wall mechanics given recent
   chest compressions, possibly underlying obstructive lung disease, and
   now bloody secretions.  Fluid overload less likely given absence of
   significant edema on x-rays.
   - Appreciate pulmonary recommendations, will obtain CTA chest for PE
   - Treat pneumonia as above with cipro
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily trials of breathing
   - f/u AFB neg. x3, now off precautions.
   - Per pulmonary will do daily sputum for cytology
   - Bronchoscopy [**2166-2-21**] showed some blood and extensive mucous plugging.
   BAL sent for cytology and culture. Concern for lung ca

   bronchus concerning for squamous ca with possible met to T6 as well as
   hilar and carinal LAD
   .

   yesterday which is greater than 50% drop.  Time course is consistent
   with possible HIT.  Heparin products d/c
d yesterday and HIT Ab sent.
   DIC labs negative.  PPI can cause thrombocytopenia, however favor
   continuing given recent GIB.  Held off starting argatroban given risk
   of bleeding and no evidence of thrombotic events at this time. HIT
   antibody negative.
   - Appreciate Hematology recommendations
   - Holding heparin products
   - Start argatroban if develops thrombosis
   - Transfuse platelets <10 or critical bleeding
   - Discontinued possible offending drugs including protonic (now on
   sucralfate), unasyn (now on cipro), heparin.
   .
